name: cutandrun-low-input-tf
title: CUT&RUN: Low-Input Transcription Factor Mapping
description: Revolutionary CUT&RUN technology for mapping transcription factor binding sites with minimal cell input (100-1000x less than ChIP-seq). Perfect for rare cell populations, limited samples, and high-resolution epigenomic profiling with superior signal-to-noise ratios.
content:
üß¨ CUT&RUN: Low-Input Transcription Factor Mapping

Revolutionary Technology for Limited Cell Numbers

CUT&RUN (Cleavage Under Targets and Release Using Nuclease) is a breakthrough chromatin profiling technology that maps transcription factor binding sites and histone modifications with 100-1000x fewer cells than traditional ChIP-seq. By using an antibody-targeted nuclease to precisely cut DNA at binding sites, CUT&RUN delivers exceptional signal-to-noise ratios with minimal background.

üéØ Why CUT&RUN Over ChIP-seq?

Game-Changing Advantages for Low-Input Studies:

üìä Minimal Cell Requirements

  • üî¨ As Few as 100 Cells: Successfully profile TF binding from tiny cell populations

  • üíâ Rare Cell Types: Study stem cells, circulating tumor cells, or sorted populations

  • üß™ Limited Biopsies: Extract maximum information from precious clinical samples

  • ‚ö° ChIP-seq Comparison: Requires 10,000-1,000,000 cells vs. CUT&RUN's 100-10,000

üé® Superior Data Quality

  • üìà Lower Background: Minimal non-specific binding and genomic DNA contamination

  • üéØ Higher Signal-to-Noise: Precise antibody-targeted cutting eliminates noise

  • üîç Better Resolution: Single-nucleotide resolution mapping of binding sites

  • üí∞ Cost Effective: Lower sequencing depth required (5-10M reads vs. 20-50M)

‚ö° Simplified Protocol

  • ‚è±Ô∏è Faster: Complete protocol in 1 day vs. 3-4 days for ChIP-seq

  • üßä No Cross-linking: Native chromatin binding reduces artifacts

  • üö´ No Sonication: Eliminates DNA shearing variability

  • ‚úÖ Direct Profiling: In situ digestion captures genuine binding events

üî¨ Technology: How CUT&RUN Works

The Antibody-Targeted Nuclease Approach:

  1. üéØ Antibody Binding: Primary antibody recognizes target transcription factor

  2. üîó Protein A-MNase: Secondary fusion protein binds antibody and carries nuclease

  3. ‚úÇÔ∏è Targeted Cleavage: Ca¬≤‚Å∫ activation triggers precise DNA cutting at binding sites

  4. üß¨ Fragment Release: Small DNA fragments diffuse out, ready for sequencing

  5. üìä Low Background: Bulk chromatin remains intact, minimizing contamination

üß™ Perfect Research Applications

üî¨ Rare Cell Populations

  • Stem Cells: Limited cell numbers in embryonic or adult stem cell niches

  • Clinical Samples: Precious patient biopsies with finite material

  • FACS-Sorted Cells: Specific cell populations isolated by flow cytometry

  • Circulating Tumor Cells: Ultra-rare cancer cells in blood samples

üß¨ Transcription Factor Studies

  • Master Regulators: Map pluripotency factors like OCT4, SOX2, NANOG

  • Cell Fate Decisions: Track TF binding during differentiation

  • Oncogenic Factors: Profile cancer-driving TFs like MYC, TP53, RUNX1

  • Developmental Biology: Study TF networks in embryonic development

üé® Epigenomic Profiling

  • Histone Modifications: H3K4me3, H3K27me3, H3K27ac with low cell input

  • Chromatin States: Active promoters, enhancers, and repressive domains

  • Regulatory Elements: High-resolution mapping of gene regulatory regions

  • Comparative Epigenomics: Profile changes across cell types or conditions

üìã Sample Sheet: Experimental Design

CSV Format with Control Samples:

CUT&RUN experiments typically include IgG controls or input samples for background normalization. The sample sheet links experimental samples to their controls:

group,replicate,fastq_1,fastq_2,control
ctcf_tf,1,ctcf_rep1_r1.fastq.gz,ctcf_rep1_r2.fastq.gz,igg_ctrl
ctcf_tf,2,ctcf_rep2_r1.fastq.gz,ctcf_rep2_r2.fastq.gz,igg_ctrl
igg_ctrl,1,igg_rep1_r1.fastq.gz,igg_rep1_r2.fastq.gz,
igg_ctrl,2,igg_rep2_r1.fastq.gz,igg_rep2_r2.fastq.gz,

Key Design Principles:

  • Biological Replicates: Minimum 2 replicates per condition for statistical power

  • IgG Controls: Essential for normalizing non-specific antibody binding

  • Matched Processing: Controls must be processed identically to samples

  • Replicate Consistency: Use same cell number and protocol across replicates

‚öôÔ∏è Analysis Pipeline Parameters

üìÅ Input/Output Configuration

  • Sample Sheet: CSV file defining experimental structure and sample-control relationships

  • Output Directory: Organized results with alignment, peaks, QC, and visualization files

üß¨ Reference Genome Selection

  • Human: GRCh37, GRCh38, hg19, hg38 - comprehensive TF binding annotations

  • Model Organisms: Mouse (GRCm38/39, mm10/39), fly, zebrafish, C. elegans

  • Custom References: Provide your own FASTA, Bowtie2 index, and GTF annotation

  • Spike-in Normalization: E. coli K12 default for cross-sample normalization

üéØ Peak Calling Strategy

SEACR (Recommended for CUT&RUN):

  • Sparse Enrichment Analysis optimized for low-background data

  • No input DNA control required (uses IgG or threshold-based calling)

  • Excellent for transcription factors with focal binding sites

  • Stringent mode reduces false positives in low-signal regions

MACS2 (Traditional ChIP-seq Method):

  • Gold-standard peak caller adapted for CUT&RUN data

  • Broader peak detection for histone modifications

  • Adjustable q-value threshold for sensitivity/specificity balance

  • Useful for comparing with existing ChIP-seq datasets

Combined Approach: Run both callers to identify high-confidence peaks

üîß Advanced Options

  • Use Control Normalization: Enable to normalize against IgG controls (recommended)

  • Duplicate Filtering: Remove PCR/optical duplicates (enabled by default)

  • Mitochondrial Filtering: Remove contaminating mitochondrial reads

  • Fragment Size Filtering: Keep fragments 120-600bp for nucleosome-bound regions

  • Spike-in Calibration: Normalize to E. coli spike-in for quantitative comparisons

üìä Comprehensive Results Output

Peak Calling Results

  • üìç Peak Coordinates: BED format files with genomic locations and scores

  • üéØ Consensus Peaks: High-confidence peaks identified by multiple methods

  • üìä Peak Annotations: Gene associations, promoter/enhancer classification

  • üìà Differential Binding: Statistical comparisons between experimental conditions

Quality Control

  • üìÑ MultiQC Report: Comprehensive HTML summary with all QC metrics

  • üìä Fragment Distribution: Nucleosome positioning and fragment size analysis

  • üéØ Peak Statistics: Number of peaks, signal strength, reproducibility

  • üîç Mapping Efficiency: Alignment rates, duplicate rates, coverage depth

Visualization Files

  • üåê BigWig Tracks: Genome browser tracks for UCSC, IGV, or WashU

  • üìä Heatmaps: Signal intensity across genomic features

  • üìà Profile Plots: Average signal at promoters, enhancers, gene bodies

  • üé® Coverage Plots: Sample-specific and differential binding visualization

Processed Data

  • üß¨ BAM Files: Aligned, filtered, and deduplicated reads

  • üìã Count Matrices: Peak-by-sample quantification for downstream analysis

  • üìä Normalization Factors: Spike-in and library size normalization values

  • üîç IGV Session: Pre-configured genome browser for immediate exploration

üéì Biological Insights You'll Gain

  • üéØ TF Binding Sites: Precise genomic locations where transcription factors regulate genes

  • üß¨ Regulatory Networks: Master regulators controlling cell identity and function

  • üîÑ Dynamic Changes: How TF binding shifts during differentiation or disease

  • üé® Chromatin Context: Relationship between TF binding and chromatin accessibility

  • ü©∫ Disease Mechanisms: Aberrant TF binding in cancer or developmental disorders

  • üíä Drug Targets: Therapeutic opportunities targeting TF-driven pathways

jobConfig.label: System Size

jobConfig.description: Select compute resources. Start with XSMALL for testing, scale up for production data.

options.label: XSMALL (4 CPUs, 15GB RAM) - Testing/nf-core test data
SMALL (8 CPUs, 30GB RAM) - Small datasets (1-3 samples)
MEDIUM (32 CPUs, 120GB RAM) - Standard datasets (5-20 samples)
LARGE (64 CPUs, 360GB RAM) - Large datasets (20-50 samples)

spec.label: Sample Sheet
spec.name: input
spec.description: CSV samplesheet with columns: group, replicate, fastq_1, fastq_2, control. Each row represents a paired-end sample. Control column links samples to their IgG controls.

spec.label: Output Directory
spec.name: outputDir
spec.description: Directory for organized analysis results including peaks, alignments, QC reports, and visualizations.

spec.label: Reference Genome
spec.name: genome
spec.description: Reference genome for read alignment and peak annotation. Choose the appropriate build for your species and experimental design.

spec.label: Peak Caller
spec.name: peakcaller
spec.description: Peak calling algorithm. SEACR is optimized for CUT&RUN's low-background data. MACS2 is traditional ChIP-seq method. Use both for high-confidence peak sets.

spec.label: Use Control Normalization
spec.name: use_control
spec.description: Normalize peak calling using IgG control samples. Recommended for reducing non-specific binding background.

spec.label: Mitochondrial Chromosome Name
spec.name: mito_name
spec.description: Mitochondrial chromosome identifier for filtering contaminating mitochondrial reads.

spec.label: Minimum Alignment Quality Score
spec.name: min_alignment_q
spec.description: Minimum MAPQ score for keeping aligned reads. Higher values (20) ensure uniquely mapped reads.

spec.label: Remove PCR Duplicates
spec.name: remove_duplicates
spec.description: Remove duplicate reads arising from PCR amplification. Recommended for accurate quantification.

spec.label: Remove Mitochondrial Reads
spec.name: remove_mito
spec.description: Filter out mitochondrial reads that don't provide gene regulation information. Recommended for cleaner data.
